rev.comment: /* Necrophilia in literature */ the Legend of Osiris and Isis
rev.diff:
Line 44: Line 44:
Published in 1930, William Faulkner's "A Rose for Emily" tells the story of a lonely house ridden woman named Emily Grierson who deals with the strange circumstances of her father, the man she loves, and her secret world of necrophilia.
Published in 1930, William Faulkner's "A Rose for Emily" tells the story of a lonely house ridden woman named Emily Grierson who deals with the strange circumstances of her father, the man she loves, and her secret world of necrophilia.
  +   +
One could argue that the [[Legend of Osiris and Isis]] involved a necrophilic act; [[Isis]] is said to have fathered [[Horus]] with the dead [[Osiris]]'s dismembered penis, albeit miraculously. According to ''Christian Origins in Egyptian Mythology'', "an ancient Egyptian relief depicts this conception by showing his mother Isis in a falcon form, hovering over an erect phallus of a dead and prone Osiris in the Underworld."<ref>http://www.godisamyth.com/regs/ez/egypt.htm</ref>
==Notable necrophiles==
==Notable necrophiles==
